title: Chap 01: Probability Theory
text:
Definition 1.1.2 Let A, B be events, subsets of S, then:
Union: The union of A and B, written \(A \cup B\) is the set of elements that belong to either A or B or both: \[ A \cup B = \{x: x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\} \] Intersection: The intersection of A and B, written \(A \cap B\) is the set of elements that belong to both A and B: \[ A \cap B = \{x: x \in A \text{ and } x \in B\} \] Complement: The complement of A, written as \(A^c\), is the set of all elements that are not in A: \[ A^c = \{x: x \notin A \} \]


Theorem 1.1.4 For any three events, A, B and C, defined on a sample space S,
\[\begin{array}{l l}
a. Commutativity    & A \cup B = B \cup A,\\
                        & A \cap B = B \cap A;\\
b. Associativity    & A \cup (B \cup C) = (A \cup B)\cup C,\\
                        & $A \cap (B \cap C) = (A \cap B)\cap C;\\
c. Distributive Laws    & A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B)\cup (A \cap C),\\
                        & $A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C);\\
d. DeMorgan's Laws & (A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c ,\\
                   & (A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c .

\end{array}\]




Definition If \(A_1, A_2, A_3, \ldots\) is a collection of sets, all defined on a sample space \(S\), then
\[\begin{align*}
\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i &= \{x \in S: x \in A_i  \text{ for some }i\},\\
\bigcap_{i=1}^\infty A_i &= \{x \in S: x \in A_i  \text{ for all }i\}.\\
\end{align*}\]



Definition 1.1.5 Two events \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint (or mutually exclusive) if \(A \cap B = 0\). The events \(A_1,A_2,\ldots\) are pairwise disjoint (or mutually exclusive) if \(A_i \cap A_j = 0 \text{ for all } i \ne j\).



Definition 1.1.6 If \(A_1,A_2,\ldots\) are pairwise disjoint and \(\bigcup_{i=0}^\infty A_i = S\), then the collection \(A_1, A_2, \dots\) forms a partition of S.





Definition 1.2.1 A collection of subsets of S is called a sigma algebra (or Borel field ), denoted by \(\mathscr{B}\), if it satifies the following three properties:

\(0 \in \mathscr{B}\) (the empty set is an element of \(\mathscr{B}\))
If \(A \in \mathscr{B}\) then \(A^c \in \mathscr{B}\) (\(\mathscr{B}\) is closed under complementation)
If \(A_1, A_2, \ldots \in \mathscr{B}\) then \(\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i \in \mathscr{B}\) (\(\mathscr{B}\) is closed under countable unions).

title: Chap 01: Probability Theory
text:
Definition 1.1.2 Let A, B be events, subsets of S, then:
Union: The union of A and B, written \(A \cup B\) is the set of elements that belong to either A or B or both: \[ A \cup B = \{x: x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\} \] Intersection: The intersection of A and B, written \(A \cap B\) is the set of elements that belong to both A and B: \[ A \cap B = \{x: x \in A \text{ and } x \in B\} \] Complement: The complement of A, written as \(A^c\), is the set of all elements that are not in A: \[ A^c = \{x: x \notin A \} \]


Theorem 1.1.4 For any three events, A, B and C, defined on a sample space S,
\[\begin{array}{l l}
a. Commutativity    & A \cup B = B \cup A,\\
                        & A \cap B = B \cap A;\\
b. Associativity    & A \cup (B \cup C) = (A \cup B)\cup C,\\
                        & $A \cap (B \cap C) = (A \cap B)\cap C;\\
c. Distributive Laws    & A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B)\cup (A \cap C),\\
                        & $A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C);\\
d. DeMorgan's Laws & (A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c ,\\
                   & (A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c .

\end{array}\]




Definition If \(A_1, A_2, A_3, \ldots\) is a collection of sets, all defined on a sample space \(S\), then
\[\begin{align*}
\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i &= \{x \in S: x \in A_i  \text{ for some }i\},\\
\bigcap_{i=1}^\infty A_i &= \{x \in S: x \in A_i  \text{ for all }i\}.\\
\end{align*}\]



Definition 1.1.5 Two events \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint (or mutually exclusive) if \(A \cap B = 0\). The events \(A_1,A_2,\ldots\) are pairwise disjoint (or mutually exclusive) if \(A_i \cap A_j = 0 \text{ for all } i \ne j\).



Definition 1.1.6 If \(A_1,A_2,\ldots\) are pairwise disjoint and \(\bigcup_{i=0}^\infty A_i = S\), then the collection \(A_1, A_2, \dots\) forms a partition of S.





Definition 1.2.1 A collection of subsets of S is called a sigma algebra (or Borel field ), denoted by \(\mathscr{B}\), if it satifies the following three properties:

\(0 \in \mathscr{B}\) (the empty set is an element of \(\mathscr{B}\))
If \(A \in \mathscr{B}\) then \(A^c \in \mathscr{B}\) (\(\mathscr{B}\) is closed under complementation)
If \(A_1, A_2, \ldots \in \mathscr{B}\) then \(\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i \in \mathscr{B}\) (\(\mathscr{B}\) is closed under countable unions).

Counting and Probabilities

Definition 1.2.17 For nonnegative integers \(n\) and \(r\), where \(n \ge r\), we define the symbol \(n \choose r\), read n choose r, as \[
  {n \choose r} = \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}
\]

Counting Prob

Definition 1.2.17 For nonnegative integers \(n\) and \(r\), where \(n \ge r\), we define the symbol \(n \choose r\), read n choose r, as \[
  {n \choose r} = \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}

title: Chap 01: Probability Theory
text:
Probabilities

Kolmogorov Axioms

Definition 1.2.4 Given a sample space \(S\) and an associated sigma algebra \(\mathscr{B}\) that satisfies

\(P(A) \ge 0\) for all \(A \in \mathscr{B}\)
\(P(S) = 1\)
If \(A_1,A_2,\ldots \in \mathscr{B}\) are pairwise disjoint, then \(P(\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty A_i) = \sum_{i=1}^\infty P(A)\)





Probability Function

Theorem 1.2.6 Let \(S = {s_1,\ldots,s_n}\) be a finite set. Let \(\mathscr{B}\) be any sigma algebra of subsets of \(S\). Let \(p_1,\ldots,p_n\) be nonnegative numbers that sum to 1. For any \(A \in \mathscr{B}\), define \(P(A)\) by \[
P(A) = \sum_{\{i:s_i \in A\}} p_i
\] (The sum over an empty set is defined to be \(0\).) Then \(P\) is a probability function on \(\mathscr{B}\). This remains true if \(S={s_1, s_2, \ldots }\) is a countable set.



Theorem 1.2.8 If \(P\) is a probability function and \(A\) is any set in \(\mathscr{B}\), then

\(P(0) = 0\) where \(0\) is the empty set;
\(P(A) \le 1\);
\(P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)\).




Theorem 1.2.9 If \(P\) is a probability function and \(A\) and \(B\) are any sets in \(\mathscr{B}\) then

\(P(B \cap A^c) = P(B) - P(A \cap B)\);
\(P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)\);
IF \(A \subset B\), then \(P(A) \le P(B)\)




Theorem 1.2.11 If \(P\) is a probability function, then

\(P(A) = \sum_{i=1}^\infty P(A \cap C_i )\) for any partition \(C_1, C_2, \ldots ;\)
\(P(\cup_{i=1}^\infty A_i )\le \sum_{i=1}^\infty P(A_i)\) for any sets $A_1, A_2, \ldots $;




Counting

Definition 1.2.17 For nonnegative integers \(n\) and \(r\), where \(n \ge r\), we define the symbol \(n \choose r\), read n choose r, as \[
{n \choose r} = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}
\]



With Replacements
Table 1.2.1 Number of possible arrangements of size \(r\) from \(n\) objects.
\[\begin{array}{c c c}
\hline
          & {Without}  & {With}  \\
          & Replacement & Replacement\\
\hline
  Ordered & \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!} & n^r \\
  Unordered & \displaystyle{ n \choose r}& \displaystyle{{n+r-1} \choose r}\\
\hline
\end{array}\]

Example: drawing five cards (Poker) from a deck of 52 cards (i.e. sampling without replacement).


Unordered arrangement of five cards = \(\displaystyle {52 \choose 5}\) = \(\dfrac{52!}{47!5!}\) = 2,598,960 \(\qquad \blacksquare\)


Four aces out of 5 cards

there are 48 (52-4) different ways to choose fifth card. \[
P (\text{four aces}) = \dfrac{48}{2,598,960} = {1}:{254,145} \qquad \blacksquare
\]

Four of a kind e.g. four queens

there are 13 ways to specify which denomination {1:King}.
there are 48 ways to select the fifth card. \[
P(\text{four of a kind}) = \dfrac{(13)(48)}{2,598,960} = \dfrac{624}{2,598,960}= {1}:{4,165} \qquad \blacksquare
\]

Exactly one pair only e.g. queen pair

outcomes for one pair only :
specify denomination for the pair
two cards from a denomination
specify the other three denonimations
specify the other three cards from the denominations


\[
  13 {4 \choose 2} {12 \choose 3} 4^3 = 1,098,240
\]
Thus,
\[
P(\text{exactly one pair})=\dfrac{1,098,240}{2,598,960} = 1:(2.58) \qquad\blacksquare
\]


Conditional Probability

Definition 1.3.2 If \(A\) and \(B\) are events in \(S\) and \(P(B) \gt 0\) , then the conditional probability of \(A\) given \(B\) , written as \(P(A|B)\) is:
\[
P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B}{P(B)}
\]

\(\\\)

Theorem 1.3.5 (Bayes’ Rule) Let \(A_1,A_2, \ldots\) be a partition of the sample space, and let B be any set. Then for each i=1,2,, \[
P(A_i|B) = \frac{P(B|A_i)P(A_i)}{\sum_{j=1}^\infty P(B|A_j)P(A_j)}
\]

\(\\\)

Definition 1.3.7 Two events \(A\) and \(B\) are statistically independent if:
\[
P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)
\]

\(\\\)

Definition 1.3.12 A collection of events \(A_1, \ldots, A_n\) are mutually independent if for any subcollection \(A_{i_1},\dots,A_{i_k}\), we have
\[
P(\bigcap_{j=1}^k A_{i_j}) = \prod_{j=1}^k P(A_{i_j}).
\]

\]
